block.p: Russians Struggle to Save Trapped Submarine Crew The Russian Navy prepared for a desperate attempt to rescue more than 100 crew members of a nuclear submarine trapped at least 450 feet beneath the Barents Sea. The submarine sank during a naval exercise, though the cause was uncertain.

Russians Struggle to Save Trapped Submarine Crew The Russian Navy prepared for a desperate attempt to rescue more than 100 crew members of a nuclear submarine trapped at least 450 feet beneath the Barents Sea. The submarine sank during a naval exercise, though the cause was uncertain.

Sainthood for the Last Czar The Russian Orthodox Church announced the canonization of Russia's last czar, Nicholas II, and his immediate family for their ''humbleness, patience and meekness'' when they were imprisoned and executed by the Bolsheviks 82 years ago.

U.N. Tribunal for Sierra Leone The Security Council agreed to set up a war crimes tribunal for Sierra Leone, but stopped short of actually establishing the court or deciding its composition and functions.
Effort to Save Congo Accord Ten African presidents met in Zambia for an urgent push to salvage the crumbling Congo peace accord and to pave the way for the deployment of United Nations peacekeepers.

Kosovo Clash Over Pollution Kosovo Serbs hurled rocks and sticks at NATO troops after the peacekeepers moved in to shut down a lead smelter pumping toxic fumes into the air in the ethnically divided city of Mitrovica. Four soldiers and at least one Serb were injured.

Iran Detains More Journalists The crackdown on reformers continued over the weekend with the detention of two writers. Both men wrote for a banned daily newspaper and recently won awards from their peers in an annual press festival.

Debate Over Collector's Post The White House has touched off a furor with the appointment of Shelby White, a wealthy New York antiquities collector, to a government committee formed to combat illicit international trade in such objects.

Clinton Hails Gore As Guardian of His Legacy President Clinton delivered a nostalgic and sentimental valedictory at the Democratic National Convention, savoring ''this moment of unprecedented good fortune'' and imploring Americans to protect his achievements by electing Vice President Al Gore to succeed him.
Neither Mr. Gore nor Senator Joseph I. Lieberman mentioned Mr. Clinton while campaigning in St. Louis.
Bill Bradley released his 390 delegates to the vice president, telling them that ''Al Gore will stand for the things we fought for in our campaign, and he deserves our support.''

Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her prime-time speech, celebrated her husband's years in office and expanded on a theme in his speech, suggesting that in addition to electing Mr. Gore president, sending her to the Senate would ensure continuation of Mr. Clinton's policies.
Representative Rick A. Lazio, campaigning in New York City, signed a document that called on Mrs. Clinton to join him in renouncing unregulated campaign contributions.
Protests near the convention turned into a rowdy confrontation as protestors threw stones at the police, who responded by firing rubber bullets.
The Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles called for an end to abortions in his invocation.

DNA Frees Texas Inmate Gov. George W. Bush said he would pardon Roy Criner, 35, who was imprisoned a decade ago for rape, after new DNA evidence convinced prosecutors and law enforcement officials that he should be freed.

Kidnapped Girl Escapes An 8-year-old girl who spent two nights shackled to the front seat of a kidnapper's car found a key that opened the lock and escaped, the police in Vallejo, Calif., said. A convicted kidnapper was charged.

$11 Million Penalty in Air Crash A federal judge ordered a defunct jet-repair contractor, SabreTech, to pay $11 million in penalties for mishandling oxygen canisters blamed for the 1996 ValuJet crash in the Everglades that killed 110 people.
Safety Recall of Go-Karts The Consumer Product Safety Commission said 91,000 motorized go-karts were being recalled by Manco Products for safety reasons.

Northwestern New Jersey Labors Under Heavy Rain Some families were allowed to return to homes they fled after Saturday's storm, though rescue officials evacuated about 300 more families from Byram Township, Sparta and other nearby towns, including a day camp with 800 children. Officials said several dams had given way, swelling rivers and streams. A storm added 4 inches of rain to the 14 that fell on Saturday, and the forecast was for more rain today.

Gas Leak Cited in Deadly Blast The explosion that leveled a town house, destroyed another and killed three people in Brooklyn last month was probably primed by a leaky pipe in the first house's basement and ignited by someone flipping a light switch, fire marshals said.

Torricelli's Miscalculation Senator Robert G. Torricelli acknowledged to New Jersey delegates to the Democratic National Convention that he had misjudged their support in his effort to usurp James E. McGreevey's place as the likely nominee for governor next year.

Report on TWA Flight 800 The National Transportation Safety Board is completing its final report on the Boeing 747 crash in 1996, a report that will be an unusually long 700 pages but that will not identify the primary cause of the crash.

Roots of Monetary Economy Archaeologists digging in Turkey have determined that the first coins of pure gold and pure silver were struck in ancient Sardis, the capital of the Lydian empire, in the time of Croesus, the sixth century B.C.

Possible Supply of Nerve Cells Scientists have spurred bone marrow cells to turn into nerve cells, raising the tantalizing possibility of an easily accessible source of replacement cells to treat brain and nerve injuries and diseases, though the work is just beginning.

Unsubstantiated Complaints Not one of the first 830 complaints of taxpayer harassment filed under a new law intended to prevent I.R.S. bullying has been upheld by the I.R.S. or its new Congressionally designated watchdog, records show. Some critics said the data showed that the concerns that had prompted the law were probably overstated.

More Action Urged on Tire Recall Plaintiffs' lawyers and safety advocates called on Firestone to widen its tire recall, and they urged consumers to replace all Firestone Wilderness AT tires on Ford Explorers immediately, including many tires that have not been recalled.
Workers and union officials at a factory in Decatur, Ill., disputed Ford's singling out of their factory as the main source of the problem.
Biotechnology Acquisition Chiron agreed to pay $700 million for PathoGenesis, a developer of antibiotics, saying the deal would help make Chiron ''a global player in infectious disease and cancer.''

Stocks in Broad Advance The Dow climbed 148.34 points, or 1.4 percent, to 11,176.14, its highest finish since April 11. The Nasdaq rose 60.22 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,849.69, while the S.& P. 500 gained 19.72 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,491.56.
